item.info: Do you play LoL (League of Legends)? Want to play with some of your fellow physicists? SPS is hoping to host a LAN party / tournament of sorts in the near future. If you're interested, you can sign up here or email SPS webmaster, Tharon Morrison at t_morrison@utexas.edu

item.name: Sunday Night Study Session
item.info: It's back! Our Sunday Night Study Session (SNSS) is in full swing! For those who haven't been, every week we invite any and all physics majors and people in physics or math classes to come by to work on homework. With many upper-division students in attendance (and some LAs for classes), when you run into problems, you won't be stuck for long. We also provide cookies, coffee, tea, etc., to help keep you <s>caffeinated</s> energized. Some come by to help or be helped! If you're interested in tutoring, making known that you're available during the night (name on a chalkboard) is a great way to earn service hours for Sigma Pi Sigma.

item.name: Sigma Pi Sigma Service Hours
item.info: Interested in joining Sigma Pi Sigma, the physics honors society? The requirements are listed on our website. For the service hour component, we will be managing that through the new HornsLink system (see below for the link). Join the SPS group and when you volunteer (like tutoring for SNSS above), submit a request for us to verify your service hours. That way, we have a nice record of volunteers and volunteer time (and it will show up on the resume HornsLink can create for you)! You input the time you worked, we sign off, then you don't have to think about it again!

item.name: Career Design Center
item.info: The College of Natural Sciences' Career Design Center is hosting several events this semester for career prep and other interesting events. This is a handy list of some of those events, which includes the CNS Career Expo on the 16th (see below).

item.name: CNS Career Expo
item.info:
The semesterly Career Expo is already almost upon us! Looking for an internship? Or maybe a full-time position starting in the summer (yes, that far in advance)? Then go to the Career Expo!!! By my count (and by that I mean Adobe's), there are at least 25 companies interested in hiring physics majors, including places as diverse as: Applied Research Laboratories (ARL) here in Austin, athenahealth, Bloomberg, Intel, Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), National Instruments, and Sandia National Laboratories. And many companies that don't have "Physics" listed as a desired major may be willing to bend the rules if you have programming experience or can convince them that you are very good at solving problems (a big part of physics).

Information on expected attire and a list of companies (and some tips) can be found on the Career Design Center's website here. If you have questions, you can contact them (info on website), or ask a fellow physicist!

item.name: Job Openings
item.info: The SPS officers get several emails each week about positions in various companies / organizations, and we want to pass them along but don't want to further increase the length of these messages. Therefore, we'll be updating our website in the coming week or two to link to information then reference it in these emails. At the moment, we have some info about a summer internship in the Petroleum and Geosystems Engineering department, positions for this semester at the non-profit Undergraduate Computational Finance, and consulting organization iRunway. If you'd like the info we have on any of these, please email us. Otherwise, we'll be posting things as they come in.
